docs.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON LONG gone are the days when laying hens, broilers, and roasters were raised in the barnyards of small farms, separated by miles from other flocks, and pecking at such bits as came their way. In today's mass production of poultry the bird that ends up on your table never sees the world outside its laying cage or chick box or vast broiler house, where 20,000 broilers are fattened at one time. Since the beginning of December, the Agriculture Department estimated last week, at least 225 million new baby chicks were prepared to contribute their bodies to the 11 billion pounds of chicken meat produced each year in this country's huge, factory-like poultry establishments. In the eight weeks between hatching and demise each bird is fed, injected or vaccinated with at least 20 antibiotics, minerals and vitamins designed to make it grow faster and protect it from the myriad diseases that chicken flesh in crowded conditions is heir to. The plump and, its grower hopes, tender broiler begins to receive preventive treatment even while its egg is developing in its mother, whose feed was laced with at least nine different antibiotics, growth stimulants, minerals and vitamins, some designed to improve the hatchability of her chicks.

headline.main: Mobile Hospitals Units to Serve 3 Counties

docs.abstract: 4 northern NJ hospitals coordinate plan to provide mobile intensive care units to assist police and local first-aid squads in life-threatening emergencies; central hot-line number will dispatch units, staffed by trained paramedics (S)
docs.snippet: SUMMIT FOUR northern New Jersey hospitals have joined in a program to provide coordinated 24-hour emergency life-support serv  ices for 800,000 residents of Union. Morris and Essex Counties.

docs.lead_paragraph: SUMMIT FOUR northern New Jersey hospitals have joined in a program to provide coordinated 24-hour emergency life-support services for 800,000 residents of Union, Morris and Essex Counties. The program, which virtually brings the emergency room to the patient in mobile intensive care units, has been developed by Overlook Hospital in Summit, Memorial General Hospital in Union and St. Barnabas Medical Center in Livingston. Mountainside Hospital in Montclair will join the network later this month.

docs.lead_paragraph: THE number of suicide attempts more than doubled in Suffolk County in 1979, and the figure is expected to rise again this year. Sociologists and specialists counseling suicide-prone individuals attribute the situation to the Island's tight economy, high divorce rate and a loss of community identification. No figures on suicide attempts are collated in Nassau County, but the police, mental-health officials and various ''hot line'' staffs say that the number of attempted suicides - and those seeking counseling who disclose past attempts - has substantially increased in the last two years.
